children.text: The host, Steve Greenberg, gives a pop quiz with three hints stating the cultural significance, references, and chart success. Explains how Monster Mash became a cultural staple.

Steve explains how in the early 1960s, there was a monster movie phenomenon inspired by the 1930s and 1940s. During the Silent film era, Universal created Frankenstein, Dracula, The Wolfman, The Mummy, and many much more. The first non-silent monster film was Frankenstein with Boris Karloff.
"Spine-tingling, blood-killing story that stuns your emotions, Frankenstein! It's alive! It's alive! It's alive!"
The films were very successful and led to many sequels. For example, Bride of Frankenstein and Draculas Daugter. There were also a lot of cross-over films with the monster characters.
This era of films was described as shock theatre.

Shock theatre would air at night. The most famous show host was John Zachary because of his spooky dialogues and characters. He knew Dick Clark who introduced him to Cameo Parkway Records. In 1958, they created a record called "Dinner with Drack," which reached number six on the Billboard charts. The national success boosted Zachary's image as a campy horror icon.

Bobby Pickett came up with the idea of Monster Mash. He was an aspiring actor and comedian who specialized in impressions. Prior to his major success, Pickett impersonated film actors as part of a group called the Cordials. Pickett began to gain traction when he impersonated Boris Karloff.

The year 1962 was the beginning of dance music in the U.S. For example, the Holly Golly, A Monkey, and the Watusi were all hit dance records. Chubby Checker's "The Twist" ignited the whole phenomenon, followed by "The Mashed Potato Time" performed by DD Sharp. James Brown debuted "(Do The) Mashed Potatoes," which became one of the top ten R&B songs in the U.S.

"Mashed Potato Time," performed by DD Sharp, was inspired by "Please Mr. Postman." There were many versions of "The Mash Potato Time" from artists like the Contours, Chris Kenner, Connie Francis, and Sam Cook.
In the summer of 1962, Bobby Pickett decided to jump on the bandwagon and make a record about movie monsters.

The record has the same airwaves and groove as "Mashed Potato Time/" The song is about all of the iconic monsters having a party and learning a new dance at Frankentein's house. In the song, Pickett largely impersonates Boris Karloff, except for one line in which he impersonates Bella Lasodi, the Universal Dracula.
"Whatever happened to my Transylvanian twist?"
Monster Mash hit number 1 in October of 1962.

After Monster Mash was written by Bobby Pickett and Lennny Capezi, they had to look for labels to produce it. They got rejected by many labels until they came across Gary S. Praxton, the head of Guard Packs Record Label. Praxton added some finishing touches like sounds of a coffin opening and a bubbling cauldron, which gave the song some character. "Monster Mash" went number one on the Hot 100 for two weeks in October.

After the Monster Mash craze, Universal started to produce comedies like The Addams Family and The Munsters using old monster sets. Music and monsters start melding together later, creating a classic theme songs.

The theme for The Munsters has been recorded and re-recorded over 150 times. It has been recorded or sampled by the Boston Pops, the London Philharmonic, and Bryan Setzer, who uses it as an opener for his shows. Even the band Fall Out Boy used The Munsters theme for their song "Uma Thurman."
Under Universal Pictures had a few more years creating monsters.

In 1963, the Mummy model kit came out, followed by other major successes like The Creature from Black Lagoon, The Hunchback of Notre Dame, and Godzilla. In 1966, Aurora released their final monster model kits in collaboration with Famous Monsters of Filmland Magazine. It features new monsters: Mary Shelley's Frankenstein, Bram Stoker's Dracula, etc. These characters did not live up to success as the OG monsters from the shock theatre era.

A new era for horror films was born in the late 60s and early 70s with "Rosemary's Baby" and "The Exorcist." Universal has had its fair share of attempts to reboot the OG monsters over the years, most notably in the 2004 film "Van Helsing" featuring Hugh Jackman, which featured Frankenstein, Dracula, and The Werewolf.

In the spring of 1973, the "Monster Mash" mysteriously reappeared on the Hot 100 and stayed on the charts for 20 weeks, reaching the top ten in the middle of August. The song got banned on the BBC because it was "too morbid."
Bobby Pickett came out with a song called "Monsters Holiday" for Christmas, and the record landed number thirty on the charts. The song sounds like the original "Monster Mash," but with sleigh bells.
"They were up to no good, didn't act like good monsters should. They found themselves a new play, they planned to rob Santa's sleigh. They were making a list and checking it twice."
As years went on, the Monster Mash lost its popularity. Pickett's original hit has cemented its place in the music industry and in the heart of many generations.
